PromiseRejectionEvent.summary: The PromiseRejectionEvent interface represents events which are sent to the global script context when JavaScript s are rejected. These events are particularly useful for telemetry and debugging purposes.

remarks.para: For details, see Promise rejection events.

PromiseRejectionEventPromise.summary:
The interface's
promise read-only property indicates the JavaScript
which was rejected. You can examine the event's
property to learn why the promise was
rejected.
PromiseRejectionEventPromise.value:
The JavaScript which was rejected, and whose rejection went
unhandled.

PromiseRejectionEventPromiseRejectionEve.summary:
The PromiseRejectionEvent()
constructor returns a new object, which
represents events fired when a JavaScript is rejected.

remarks.para:
With promise rejection events, it becomes possible to detect and report promises which
fail and whose failures go unnoticed. It also becomes easier to write a global handler
for errors.

There are two types of PromiseRejectionEvent:
is sent by the JavaScript runtime when a promise is
rejected but the rejection goes unhandled. A event is
emitted if a promise is rejected but the rejection is caught by a rejection handler.

PromiseRejectionEventPromiseRejectionEve.returns: A new PromiseRejectionEvent object configured as specified by the parameters.

PromiseRejectionEventReason.summary:
The reason read-only
property is any JavaScript value or which provides the reason
passed into . This in theory provides information about
why the promise was rejected.
PromiseRejectionEventReason.value:
A value or object which provides information you can use to understand why the promise
was rejected. This could be anything from an error code to an object with text, links,
and whatever else you might wish to include.
